name: Kepler-115
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-115 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-115 is a star with 1.424 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.21 times its radius. It is located 2070.99 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-115 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-115 b

Kepler-115 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 2.40 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-115.

The mass of Kepler-115 b is 1.18 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-115 b is 1.09 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-115 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-115 c

Kepler-115 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 8.99 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-115.

The mass of Kepler-115 c is 9.54 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-115 c is 2.6 that of Earth. At 9.54 Earth masses, Kepler-115 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-115, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
